Authors: Soesilo P.K.M., Gunadi W., Arimbi I.R.
Title: The effect of endorser and corporate credibility on perceived risk and consumer confidence: The case of technologically complex products
Affiliations: Business Management & Marketing Program, Management Department, BINUS Business School International Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Business Management Program, Management Department, BINUS Business School Master Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Soesilo, P.K.M., Business Management & Marketing Program, Management Department, BINUS Business School International Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Gunadi, W., Business Management Program, Management Department, BINUS Business School Master Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Arimbi, I.R., Business Management Program, Management Department, BINUS Business School Master Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: This research aims to examine the effect of corporate credibility and endorser credibility on consumers’ perceived risk and confidence in purchasing a technologically complex product. Further, this research investigates whether interaction of corporate and endorser credibility in ads can help consumers improve their perception toward the risk and confidence to purchase the product. An experimental study with a 2 (endorser credibility: high vs. low) × 2 (corporate credibility: high vs. low) full-factorial, between-subjects design was used to see the interaction effect of both corporate and endorser credibility on consumer perceived risk and consumer confidence to purchase a product. In a technologically complex product such as smartphones, consumers’ perceived risk was found to be lower when the product was produced by a credible company but endorsed by a less credible source, than when it was produced by a less credible company but endorsed by a more credible source. Consumer confidence in purchasing the product was also higher when the product was produced by a credible company but endorsed by a less credible source, than when it was produced by a less credible company but endorsed by a more credible source. © 2018, © 2018 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
Author Keywords: consumer confidence; Corporate credibility; Elaboration Likelihood Model; endorser credibility; perceived risk; purchase decision; technologically complex product

Title: The effect of information exposure of contract manufacturing practice on consumers' perceived risk, perceived quality, and intention to purchase private label brand

Authors: Tussyadiah S.P., II, Kausar D.R., Soesilo P.K.M.
Title: The Effect of Engagement in Online Social Network on Susceptibility to Influence
Source title: Journal of Hospitality and Tourism Research
Affiliations: University of Surrey, United Kingdom; Pancasila University, Indonesia; Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Tussyadiah, S.P., II, University of Surrey, United Kingdom; Kausar, D.R., Pancasila University, Indonesia; Soesilo, P.K.M., Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Abstract: The effect of consumer participation in online social networking activities on their susceptibility to influence is investigated in a context of restaurant consumption. This research identified a positive relationship between consumers engagement in social networking sites (SNS) on their susceptibility to global consumption influence, which is a multidimensional factor consisting of conformity to trend, social prestige, and quality perception. Furthermore, consumer engagement in SNS and susceptibility to global consumption influence positively affect social influence on SNS. That is, consumers with higher participation in SNS are more prone to global consumer convergence and peer influence on SNS. As implications for tourism and hospitality businesses, strategies to manage consumer-to-consumer communication on social media are suggested. © 2015, © The Author(s) 2015.
Author Keywords: social influence; social media; social network; susceptibility

Authors: Wang S.-C., Soesilo P.K., Zhang D.
Title: Impact of Luxury Brand Retailer Co-Branding Strategy on Potential Customers: A Cross-Cultural Study
Affiliations: Department of Marketing, College of Business and Public Affairs, West Chester University, West Chester, PA, United States; Department of Marketing, Binus Business School, Binus University, Jakarta, Indonesia; College of Staten Island, City University of New York, New York, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wang, S.-C., Department of Marketing, College of Business and Public Affairs, West Chester University, West Chester, PA, United States; Soesilo, P.K., Department of Marketing, Binus Business School, Binus University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Zhang, D., College of Staten Island, City University of New York, New York, NY, United States
Abstract: ABSTRACT: This study examines how consumers from two different cultures react to the luxury brand retailer co-branding strategy. A 2 (Familiarity: Familiar vs. Unfamiliar) × 2 (Product Fit: Fit vs. Unfit) × 2 (Brand Fit: Fit vs. Unfit) × 2 (Country: U.S. vs. Indonesia) between-subjects design was conducted. The results show that co-branding with retailers is not a good strategy for luxury brands in Indonesia, which is characterized by a high level of collectivism. However, consumers in the U.S., which is characterized by a low level of collectivism, demonstrate a positive attitude change toward the luxury brand when they are not familiar with the luxury brand or when the luxury brand collaborates with a high-end retailer. This study provides some valuable insights for luxury brands regarding their expansion strategy into foreign countries. One contribution is that we demonstrate that cross-cultural theories on brand extension and co-branding literature might not be applied to luxury brands. We find that Hofstede's power distance and individualism/collectivism dimensions could be used to explain the discrepancy. We also provide valuable insights for co-branding strategy for luxury brands. © 2015, Copyright © Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: brand extension; brand management; co-branding; cross-culture; Luxury brand

Authors: Wang S.-C., Soesilo P.K., Zhang D., Anthony Di Benedetto C.
Title: The impact of luxury brand-retailer co-branding strategy on consumers' evaluation of luxury brand image: The case of Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Wang, S.-C.; Soesilo, P.K.; Zhang, D.; Anthony Di Benedetto, C.
Abstract: Luxury goods manufacturers may find it profitable to enter a different demographic segment, and several strategies are available to do so. Nevertheless, such market expansion can be risky, and the luxury goods company must avoid tarnishing the equity contained in the luxury brand. This study examines the effects of a co-branding strategy between luxury brands and retailers on consumers' evaluation of the luxury brand's image. We use information integration theory (IIT) as the basis for our study, as it can be used to explore how attitudes are formed and changed as new information is combined with existing cognitions and thoughts. A theoretical model based on IIT is built and empirically tested using a sample of 240 Taiwanese adult consumers. We conduct an experimental survey study in which we manipulate luxury brand familiarity and product and brand fit between luxury brand and the co-brand, and assess priorattitudes and post-attitudes toward the luxury brand and attitudes toward the co-brand. We find support for many of our hypotheses: prior-attitudes toward the luxury brand is positively related to the attitude toward the co-brand, brand fit is related to attitudes toward the co-brand, and brand fit is marginally related to the post-attitude toward the luxury brand. Other hypotheses, however (such as those regarding product fit) were not supported. We conclude by discussing our theoretical and managerial contributions. © 2012 by Emerald Group Publishing Limited.
Author Keywords: Brand evaluation; Brand image; Co-branding; Luxury brand; Retailer marketing strategy
